known_pitfalls: F1_score_bias: F1 score sensitive to contamination rate; contamination rates below 1% or above 10% can produce unreliable results
threshold_selection_problem: No principled method for anomaly score threshold selection; manual tuning required per dataset
evaluation_protocol_bias: Biased evaluation protocols can artificially inflate F1 scores (Amini et al. 2021)
anomaly_overfitting: Direct reconstruction models can memorize anomalies instead of learning normal patterns
homophily_assumption_violation: GNN assumption (similar nodes connect) fails when anomalies have similar neighbors to normal nodes
over_smoothing: Deep GNN stacking leads to indistinguishable normal and anomalous representations
label_scarcity: True anomaly labels are rare and expensive to obtain
train_test_contamination: Improper separation of anomaly types between train and test sets
computational_scaling: Latency increases significantly above 1500 dimensions; throughput peaks at 1500 dimensions
anomaly_memorization: Models may memorize specific anomaly patterns rather than learning generalizable normal behavior
edge_feature_neglect: Many GAEs overlook edge characteristics, limiting performance on rich network data
graph_structure_assumptions: Assumes fixed, known graph structure; struggles with dynamic and partially observed graphs
multi_type_anomaly_tradeoff: Single-type anomaly detection (node, edge, subgraph) causes trade-offs in multi-type scenarios
dynamic_graph_cost: Temporal modeling adds significant computational overhead
interpretability_gap: GNN decisions difficult to interpret; 'why is this node anomalous' remains challenging
heterogeneous_network_limitation: Most methods designed for homogeneous graphs; heterogeneous variants less mature
causal_correlation_confusion: Correlation does not imply causality in GNN anomaly analysis
poisoning_vulnerability: Limited study of adversarial/manipulated anomalies and robustness to attacks
fairness_bias: Emerging concern in supervised settings; biased detection across different node populations
dataset_specific_overfitting: High variance in results across datasets (F1 0.75-0.99) suggests dataset-specific tuning

notes: This evidence sheet synthesizes quantitative findings from 15+ peer-reviewed papers on Graph Neural Network-based anomaly detection. Key findings: (1) Contrastive learning methods (EAGLE, ANEMONE) now outperform reconstruction-based methods by ~15%, achieving AUC 0.88-0.95 and F1 0.85-0.97. (2) Supervised methods achieve highest performance (F1 0.85-0.99) but require extensive labeled data. (3) Semi-supervised methods provide practical balance with F1 0.80-0.95 using 1-10% labeled data. (4) Critical pitfall: F1-score sensitivity to contamination rate requires careful evaluation protocol design. (5) Computational scaling degrades significantly above 1500 feature dimensions. (6) State-of-art methods leverage multiple techniques: Transformers for temporal dependencies, multi-view contrastive learning for representation robustness, and hybrid architectures combining multiple GNN types. (7) Open challenges: interpretability, threshold selection, dynamic graphs, and multi-type anomaly detection. Research shows trend toward deeper theoretical understanding and practical hybrid approaches.

methodology_notes.metric_selection_caution: F1-score is most reported but highly sensitive to contamination rate; AUC-ROC is more robust for imbalanced datasets
methodology_notes.contamination_assumption: Typical papers assume 1-10% anomaly rate; real-world rates often different; metric results may not transfer
methodology_notes.benchmark_variance: Wide range of results (F1 0.75-0.99) across papers primarily due to dataset differences, not method differences
methodology_notes.evaluation_best_practice: Report both AUC and F1 with explicit contamination rates; use multiple datasets; validate threshold selection
methodology_notes.computational_reporting: Most papers underreport computational costs; training often takes days on GPU; inference typically milliseconds
methodology_notes.theoretical_gaps: No theoretical guarantees on detection performance; mostly empirical evaluations; over-smoothing problem unresolved

future_research_priorities: Develop principled, theoretically-grounded threshold selection methods independent of dataset

Incorporate causal frameworks for interpretable anomaly explanation

Create standardized benchmark evaluation protocols to reduce metric variance
Design efficient dynamic graph anomaly detection with temporal memory constraints
Explore few-shot and meta-learning approaches for detection with minimal anomaly examples
